Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Intelligent Malware Detection Utilizing Novel File Relation-Based Features and Resilient Techniques for Adversarial Attacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Malware (e.g., viruses, worms, and Trojans) is software that deliberately fulfills the harmful intent of an attacker. It has been used as a major weapon by the cyber-criminals to launch a wide range of attacks that cause serious damages and significant financial losses to many Internet users. To protect legitimate users from these attacks, the most significant line of defense against malware is anti-malware software products, which predominately use signature-based methods to recognize threats. However, driven by considerable economic benefits, malware attackers are using automated malware development toolkits to quickly write and modify malicious codes that can evade detection by anti-malware products. In order to remain effective, the anti-malware industry calls for much more powerful methods that are capable of protecting the users against new threats and are more difficult to evade. The broader impacts of this work include benefits to the society at large by making cyberspace more secure and resilient to cyber-attacks. The project integrates research with education through curriculum development activities and engages graduate and undergraduate students in research. It is also expected to increase the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women.

The goal of this project is to design and develop intelligent and resilient solutions against malware attacks. The project is focused on the following research aims: (1) design novel relation-based features (e.g., file co-occurrence, file co-location, and bundled installations) that are more robust and harder to evade in malware detection; (2) design and develop an effective semi-supervised learning framework utilizing both content-based and relation-based features for malware detection; and (3) design and develop resilient techniques against adversarial attacks on machine learning/data mining based models. The techniques developed by this project will create a resilient platform, at both feature and model levels, against adversarial malware attacks. Furthermore, the proposed techniques are designed to be arm race capable, and can be used in other cyber security domains, such as anti-spam, fraud detection, and counter-terrorism. Through this project, a joint computer security lab will be established which aims at creating innovations for intelligent and resilient defenses against malware attacks as well as other cybersecurity threats.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Malware (e.g., viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware and scamware) is software that deliberately fulfills the harmful intent of an attacker, which has been used as a major weapon by cybercriminals to launch a wide range of attacks that cause serious damages and significant financial losses to users in the cyberspace. To secure cyberspace, this project aims to design and develop intelligent and resilient techniques against evolving malware attacks. By the design of novel relation-based features and the development of robust representation learning and classification models, this project has created a resilient platform, at both feature and model levels, against adversarial malware attacks. In particular, under the support of this grant, the team has had 23 papers published in 2019-2020; and the research outcomes have been widely disseminated to research and industry community through project website, invited talks as well as publications in recognized journals (e.g., IEEE TKDE, IEEE TCI, JBHI, KAIS) and in proceedings of highly competitive conferences with acceptance rate about or less than 20% (e.g., IJCAI'2020, SIGKDD'2020, ICDM'2020, ACSAC'2020, WWW'2019, AAAI'2019, IJCAI'2019, ICDM'2019, and CIKM'2019). With the support of this grant, the Principal Investigator (PI) also received the prestigious CSE Research Award (2019-2020) at Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), the MetroLab Innovation of the Month (May 2020), the IJCAI Early Career Spotlight (2019), and the AICS 2019 Challenge Problem Winner.

The broader impacts of this project include benefits to the society at large by making cyberspace more secure and resilient to evolving malware attacks and other cybersecurity threats. The proposed algorithms and developed techniques in this project are also applicable to other disciplines, such as social network analysis, node classification in data mining and machine learning, etc. The project has integrated research with education through curriculum development, K-12 outreach activities and engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research (e.g., four PhD students have been recruited and two master students have graduated). A cybersecurity lab has been established through this project, and it has also increased the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women (e.g., currently, 37.5% students in the PI's lab are females, and an underrepresented female high-school student has been working with the PI on machine learning driven research related to this project).

The proposed algorithms and developed techniques in this project are also applicable to other disciplines, such as social network analysis, node classification in data mining and machine learning, etc. The project has integrated research with education through curriculum development, K-12 outreach activities and engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research (e.g., four PhD students have been recruited and two master students have graduated).
